title-group.article-title: Modification of polylactic acid fabric by two lipolytic enzyme hydrolysis

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Clothing and Textiles, Sookmyung Women’s University, Yongsan-gu, Seoul 140-742, Korea
2Department of Clothing and Textiles, Sookmyung Women’s University, Yongsan-gu, Seoul 140-742, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Wha Soon Song, Department clothing and textiles, Sookmyung Women’s University, Yongsan-gu, Seoul 140-742, Korea. Email: doccubi@sm.ac.kr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Polylactic acid (PLA) has received considerable attention as a biomass material in the textile industry. To use PLA fiber in the textile industry, suitable post-processing is needed. To establish enzymatic finishing of PLA fibers, we evaluated the hydrolytic activities of two representative lipolytic enzymes; lipase and esterase. In addition, we established the optimal hydrolytic treatment conditions of each enzyme. Results showed that the optimal lipase and esterase treatment conditions are a pH of 8.0, a temperature of 40°C, a concentration of 10% owf, and a calcium chloride concentration of 10 mM. PLA fabrics experienced a weight loss of about 0.7% from enzyme treatment with no loss of tensile strength. Biodeterioration due to enzymatic hydrolysis were observed in scanning electron microscopy images. There was an approximately twofold improvement in moisture regain by enzymatic hydrolysis. Finally, X-ray diffractometry identified a new peak localized at 2θ = 18.5° after enzyme treatment. The degree of crystallinity was increased and the crystallite size was decreased.

body.p: Polylactic acid (PLA) has received considerable attention as a biomass material in the textile industry. PLA is linear aliphatic thermoplastic polyester made of lactic acid (2-hydroxy propionic acid) building blocks and can be derived from 100% renewable sources such as corn.1,2 PLA fibers are highly marketable owing to the low unit cost of their raw materials and are biodegradable. Therefore, they have the potential to replace conventional petrochemical-based polymers in industry.3 With the increasing interest in environment, the usage of PLA has expanded to not only technical textile such as nonwoven, plastic paper, packing material or films, but also clothing textiles.3 In addition, PLA fiber is similar to polyethylene terephthalate (PET) fiber in terms of the Young’s modulus, glass-transition temperature, and density. Hence, PLA has received attention as a possible alternative to PET fibers in the garment industry because its ability to regain moisture is superior to that of PET, having good hand of drape and feel, and its excellent shape retention and crease resistant.4 However, its resistance to hydrolysis is worse than that of other synthetic fibers such as polyesters, nylon, and polypropylene (PP). In general, PLA fabrics are dyed with disperse dye, however, when treated with PET conditions, PLA fabrics could be damaged since PLA has a low glass-transition temperature.5,6 Therefore, suitable conditions of dyeing or finishing PLA fiber must be done carefully and confirmed because of its limited solubility in other chemicals.1

Among the suitable finishing for using PLA fibers in the textile industry, enzymatic processing, one of the more popular eco-friendly processing methods, is suggested.7 This method was first proposed and introduced as a biotechnology option because it is compatible with existing equipment and hence can be expected to have reduced costs, energy requirements, and water pollution. Enzymatic processing does not cause environmental pollution, and it is beneficial to the fiber because it minimizes fiber damage. It has been particularly encouraged for use with natural, synthetic, and recycled fibers, and it has proven to be effective and environmentally friendly.8–14 Unlike pre-treatments such as alkaline treatment on PLA fabrics, when treated with enzymes, there will be no fiber damage, but some properties such as hydrophilicity will be increased. However, there have been few comprehensive studies presented to show the improvement in the properties of PLA fibers when they are subjected to enzyme hydrolysis. Furthermore, there are a few studies on lipases;3,15 however, there are no studies on esterase, which has characteristics similar to lipases for the hydrolysis of PLA fabric. In addition, to enhance the effect of enzyme hydrolysis, special additives such as dissociable cofactor or metal ions may be involved in the catalytic reaction.16 These are enzyme activators.11,12 Metal ions associated with enzyme hydrolysis are Ca2+ and Mg2+; enzyme activators in the area of textile processing include L-cysteine, sodium sulfite, sodium chloride, and calcium chloride.17 In general, lipolytic enzymes show higher activation when Ca2+ ions are added,18 so CaCl2 must also be added to ensure an appropriate lipase performance.19

The purpose of this study is to investigate the effects of enzymatic hydrolysis on PLA fabrics by lipase and esterase. For this, commercial lipase from Candida cylindracea and esterase from porcine pancreas were used and compared for their effectiveness as enzymes on the hydrolysis. These two lipolytic enzymes are known to have outstanding capacity to hydrolyze ester bonds in PLA fibers.3 In addition, CaCl2 was added to the enzymatic solution and evaluated its effect as an activator when PLA fiber is subjected to enzyme hydrolysis. Furthermore, the mechanical properties of the enzyme-treated PLA fibers were determined based on weight loss, tensile strength, and X-ray scattering diffractometry results, and then surface morphologies of the PLA fibers were observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Finally, the effects of the surface modification of PLA fibers were assessed by measuring the moisture regain and surface wettability.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
One hundred percent PLA yarn of 84 dtex with 72 DTY-type filaments was supplied by Huvis. PLA fabrics were woven to the specification listed in Table 1 for the experiments. As the enzyme, a lipase from C. cylindracea and esterase from P. pancreas manufactured by Sigma was used (Table 2). Tris (hydroxymethyl) amino methane (pKa = 8.06 at 20°C; Sigma Chemical Co., USA) was used as a buffer for the enzyme. p-Nitrophenlybutyrate (p-NPB, Sigma Chemical Co., USA), sodium phosphate monobasic (pKa = 7.2, Sigma Chemical Co., USA), sodium phosphate dibasic (pKa = 7.2, Sigma Chemical Co., USA), Triton X-100, and sodium chloride were used for measuring the hydrolytic activity of the enzymes. Calcium chloride (Junsei Chemicals, Japan) was used as an enzyme activator. Ethyl alcohol (Duksan Pure Chemicals, Korea) was used for enzymatic inactivation of the samples. Table 1.
Characteristics of fabric
Fabric (%) Yarn Count (dtex) Fabric Count (yarn/inch) Weight (g/m2) Thickness (mm)
PLA 100 84 90 × 68 56.83 0.132
Table 2.
Characteristics of enzymes20,21
Enzyme Source Activity Form Manufacturer
Lipase (3.1.1.3) Candida cylindracea 2 U*/mg Powder Fluka
Esterase (3.1.1.1) Porcine pancreas 15 U**/mg Crude Sigma
*
1 unit is the amount of enzyme that releases 1 µmol of oleic acid per minutes at pH 8.0 at 40°C. **
1 unit is the amount of enzyme that releases 1 µmol of ethyl butyrate to butyric acid and ethanol per minutes at pH 8.0 at 25°C.

sec.title: Enzymatic treatment
sec.p: All enzymatic treatment of the PLA fabrics was performed in a 50 mM buffer with a liquor-to-fabric ratio of 100:1. Hydrolytic activity was measured at different pH, temperatures, enzyme concentrations, and CaCl2 concentrations for 60 min. PLA fabrics were treated with enzyme at 150 rpm using a shaking water bath (BS-21, Jeio Tech., Korea). Following treatment, the residual enzyme in all of the treated samples was inactivated and denatured using 70% ethanol. After inactivation, the samples were thoroughly washed by sonication for 15 min, washed with distilled water at a liquor-to-fabric ratio of 100:1, and then dried at room temperature.

sec.title: Hydrolytic activity
sec.p: The hydrolytic activity of the enzyme was measured according to methods of Helistö and Korpela22 and Barbosa et al.23 with an ultraviolet–visible (UV-Vis) spectrophotometer (M-3000, Scinco Co. Ltd., Korea). For measuring activities of lipase and esterase, suitable substrate, p-NPB, for enzyme was chosen.24 PLA fabric weighing 0.5 g was mixed with 50 ml of 100 mM sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0), to which was added 0.1 M sodium chloride and 0.3% (v/v) Triton X-100. Then, 2 mM p-NPB was added to a dilute 0.1 mM solution volume of 0.7 ml. To measure the p-nitophenyl (p-NP) groups released from the substrate, a control was prepared without enzymes. Immediately after enzymatic treatment, the extinction of the released p-NP was measured spectrophotometrically at 400 nm against the reagent blank. Each test was repeated five times. The hydrolytic activity of enzymes was calculated based on absorbance (ABS) using the following equation: Hydrolytic activity=ABSenzyme+PLA fibers-ABSbuffer+PLA fibers

sec.title: Weight loss
sec.p: The weight loss of the PLA fabrics was evaluated by measuring the dry weight of the fabrics. The samples were dried in a conventional dry oven at 105°C for 90 min and then weighed in a closed weighing bottle after being cooled in an automatic desiccator. The percentage weight loss was calculated as follows: Weight loss (%)=W1-W2W1×100 where W1 and W2 are the dry weights of the fabrics before and after treatment, respectively.

sec.title: Tensile strength
sec.p: The tensile strengths of the untreated and enzyme-treated fabrics were determined using a digital tensile strength tester (ASA-211-1, Asia Testing Machines Co., Korea) by the strip method according to KS K 0521. The average results of five test runs are reported.

sec.title: Surface morphology
sec.p: The surface morphology of the fabrics was analyzed using SEM (S-4800, Hitachi, Japan) after the samples were plated with osmium.

sec.title: Moisture regain
sec.p: Moisture regain of the fabrics was determined according to ASTM D 629-99 by comparing the dry weight and moist weight of the enzyme-treated PLA fabrics. Samples were dried in an oven at 105°C for 1 h and then weighed after being cooled in a desiccator for 30 min. Moisture conditioning was carried out at 20°C and 65% relative humidity for 24 h. The moisture regain was calculated using the following equation: Moisture regain (%)=Wm-WdWd×100 where Wm is the weight of the fabric in the moisture equilibrium state at 20°C and 65% relative humidity, and Wd is the weight of the fabric dried at 105°C.

sec.title: Surface wettability
sec.p: The water contact angle (WCA) was used to assess the surface wettability of PLA fabrics, thereby indicating changes in hydrophilicity. The WCA was determined using the contact angle measurement system (KRÜSS DSA 100, KRÜSS Inc., Germany).

sec.title: Crystallinity
sec.p: The crystallinity of the fabrics was measured with X-ray diffraction (XRD; X’pert APD, Philips, USA) under the following operating conditions: 40 kV and 30 mA at a wavelength λ of 1.5406 Å. The relative intensity was recorded in a scattering range (2θ) of 5°–40° in steps of 0.03°. The degree of crystallinity was calculated using the following equation: Degree of crystallinity (%)=AcAa+Ac×100 where Aa is the area of the amorphous region and Ac is the area of the crystal region from integral extent.

sec.title: Hydrolytic activity of lipase and esterase
sec.p: The activity of an enzyme strongly depends on the pH and temperature. Below the optimum pH and temperature, the enzyme, a protein, is denatured or inactivated, which decreases enzyme activity.16,25,26 In addition, because pH changes with the temperature, the pH and temperature must be considered together when studying enzyme hydrolysis. Thus, the hydrolytic activities of the enzyme were measured at various pH and temperatures by UV-Vis photometry using p-NPB in this study.

Figures 1 and 2 indicate the hydrolytic activity of the enzyme on PLA fibers at pH 7.0–11.0, temperatures of 30–70°C, and enzyme concentrations of 1–200% owf. All experiments were performed with 10% of the enzyme concentrations for 60 min. As shown in Figure 1(a), the hydrolytic activity of the lipase shaped the fluent increase curve at pH 7.0 and 9.0 with increasing temperature until 40°C. Over 40°C, the hydrolytic activity rapidly decreased to produce a bell curve. At pH 8.0, the highest point of the bell curve was 50°C; above 50°C, the hydrolytic activity decreased. At pH 10.0 and 11.0, the hydrolytic activity kept decreasing with increasing temperature. This is because the enzyme is very sensitive to alkaline pH and is denatured at higher temperatures.3,16 At the same temperature, the hydrolytic activity was the highest at pH 8.0, followed by at pH 9.0 and 7.0. In addition, hydrolytic activity decreased by 40% at pH 10.0 and 11.0. In general, for most of the enzymes, the optimum pH is in the neutral range of 7.0–9.0, and an alkaline medium destroys the overall structure of the enzyme.16 Thus, the dependence of enzyme activity on pH often takes the form of a bell-shaped titration curve with the maximum usually in the neutral range (pH optimum).16 In this study, the hydrolytic activity was the highest at pH 8.0 and a temperature of 50°C; however, the activity was unstable depending on the pH levels. In contrast, the hydrolytic activity at a pH of 8.0 and temperature of 40°C indicated similar values to that under the previous conditions but was stable regardless of the various pH values. Figure 1.
Hydrolytic activity of lipase (a) and esterase (b) depending on pH and temperature (treatment conditions: 10% owf of enzymes for 60 min). Figure 2.
Hydrolytic activity of enzymes depending on enzyme concentration (treatment conditions: pH 8.0 at 40°C for 60 min).

Figure 1(b) shows the hydrolytic activity of the esterase depending on various pH levels; the highest activity was at pH 8.0 for most temperatures and showed the lowest activity at pH 7.0. The hydrolytic activity by esterase at pH 8.0 and 40°C was twice as high as that treated at pH 7.0 and 40°C. The hydrolytic activity shaped the fluent increase curve as temperature increased until 40°C. Over 40°C, the hydrolytic activity rapidly decreased and showed a bell curve at pH 8.0 and 8.5. At pH 7.0, 9.0, and 9.5, the hydrolytic activity plateaued from 30 to 50°C and then increased until 60°C. Above 60°C, the hydrolytic activity decreased rapidly. Enzyme activity increases with temperature up to the optimum temperature, beyond which hydrolytic activity decreases sharply as the tertiary structure is disrupted through thermal agitation leading to denaturation.26 The hydrolytic activity decreased sharply when treated at a temperature of 60°C at all pH levels. When treated with esterase under 60°C, the gap in hydrolytic activity was bigger depending on pH levels than on temperature values. In other words, the effects of pH on esterase hydrolysis are important, and the optimum pH must be established when esterase treatment. Therefore, the optimal conditions for maximum hydrolysis were identified to be pH 8.0 and temperature of 40°C.

Figure 2 shows the hydrolytic activity of enzymes on PLA fibers in the enzyme concentration range 1–200% owf at pH 8.0 and 40°C for 60 min. The hydrolytic activity demonstrated a linear increase as the enzyme concentration increased. However, it coagulated at 50% owf. As coagulation occurred, the hydrolytic activity became unstable. Hydrolytic activity dependent on enzyme concentration is unstable because the enzyme reacts with the substrate and results in a state of equilibrium; however, some of the denatured enzyme protein produces coagulation in the solution when excess enzyme is used. That is, when measuring enzymatic activity, the turbid solution made from coagulation effects the absorbance of enzymatic activity, so the solution absorbance could be increased.3,27 In this study, we generally discretized the enzyme concentration at 10% owf for lipase and esterase before solidification.

Figure 3 indicates the effect of an activator on the hydrolytic activity of PLA fibers subjected to enzyme hydrolysis in an activator concentration range of 1–100 mM. As the activator concentration was increased, the hydrolytic activity of lipase and esterase increased. As shown in Figure 3, the hydrolytic activity was improved by about 2.5-fold by lipase treatment and 3.0-fold by esterase treatment, respectively, when 10 mM of CaCl2 was added. However, when 30 mM of CaCl2 was added, turbidity occurred in the solution. This is because at low salt concentrations, the solubility of an enzyme increases; however, the high level of interaction between the added ions and aqueous solvent reduces the interaction between the protein and water, leading to precipitation of the enzyme from the solution.27 Therefore, CaCl2 promotes the hydrolytic activity of lipase and esterase, and the optimum concentration is 10 mM. Consequently, we established that the optimal conditions of lipase and esterase for maximum hydrolysis of PLA fiber are pH 8.0, a temperature of 40°C, enzyme concentration of 10% owf, and an activator concentration of 10 mM for 60 min. Figure 3.
Effect of an activator on hydrolytic activity of enzymes (treatment conditions: pH 8.0 at 40°C for 60 min with 10% owf lipase; pH 8.0 at 40°C for 60 minutes with 10% owf of esterase).

sec.title: Physical changes
sec.p:
The physical changes in enzyme-treated PLA fabrics were measured based on the weight loss, tensile strength, and surface morphology. Figure 4 shows (a) the weight loss and (b) the tensile strength of PLA fabrics treated by enzyme under optimum hydrolytic activity conditions. As shown in the figure, enzymatic treatments made no big differences in tensile strength of PLA fabrics. In addition, all data were analyzed statistically at a 95% confidence interval. With enzyme treatment, the weight loss of the PLA fabrics was 0.62% by lipase and 0.75% by esterase, respectively, since the ester bonds of the PLA fiber were hydrolyzed; at this level of weight loss, the tensile strength did not decrease significantly. Considering that the weight loss was by about 0.7%, few decrease in tensile strength in a 95% confidence interval was a reasonable result. Figure 4.
Weight loss (a) and tensile strength (b) of enzyme-treated PLA fabrics at optimum hydrolytic activity conditions (treatment conditions: pH 8.0, temperature of 40°C, enzyme concentration of 10% owf in the presence of 10 mM of CaCl2 for 60 min).

Figure 5 shows the surface morphology of PLA fabrics treated with enzyme under optimum hydrolytic activity conditions. No differences were observed between untreated and enzyme-treated PLA fabrics. This implies that the hydrolysis of the PLA fabrics was concentrated on the cleavage of the ester bond of the polymer; hence, some weight loss occurred; however, no noticeable degradation such as cracks and fibrils was detected. At 10,000× magnification, the untreated surface was clear; however, the enzyme-treated surface had fine particles, microbubbles, on the surface of the fiber. These fine particles could be biodeterioration,28 which occurred at the surface of the fiber with activation of enzyme. It can adhere to the surface of the fiber, so pore structure or size, and moisture regain could be changed.29 As a result, we confirmed that hydrolysis on the surface of the fiber was initiated by microbubbles.30 Figure 5.
SEM images of enzyme-treated PLA fabrics at optimum hydrolytic activity conditions (treatment conditions: pH 8.0, temperature of 40°C, enzyme concentration of 10% owf in the presence of 10 mM of CaCl2 for 60 min).
On the basis of an assessment of the weight loss, tensile strength, and surface morphology, we concluded that enzymatic hydrolysis resulted in physical changes to PLA fabrics.

sec.title: Structural analysis
sec.p:
The structural change of PLA fiber was evaluated using XRD. Figure 6 shows the XRD spectra of PLA fabrics treated by enzymes under optimum hydrolytic activity conditions. Two crystalline reflections were observed in the 2θ range of 5°–40°. The crystal peak of the untreated sample was localized at 2θ = 16° and 28°. This supports the results of previous work.3 The degree of crystallinity of untreated PLA fabrics was calculated to be 42%, and those of lipase- and esterase-treated PLA fabrics were calculated to be 67% and 44%, respectively. Figure 6.
XRD Spectrum of enzyme-treated PLA fabrics at optimum hydrolytic activity conditions (treatment conditions: pH 8.0, temperature of 40°C, enzyme of 10% owf in the presence of 10 mM of CaCl2 for 60 min).

In addition, as shown by the highest crystal peak near 16°, the integral width was narrowed by enzymatic treatment; this means that the crystallite size of the polymer was decreased. In addition, enzymatic treatment caused a third peak at 18.5° to appear, indicating morphological changes. The new peak indicates a physical change in the short chains of polymers that are more mobile due to hydrolysis of the amorphous region of PLA polymer.31 Enzymes, especially those originating from the porcine pancreas, Candida cylindracea, and Rhizopus arrhieus hydrolyze the amorphous region of the PLA polymer.32 The new peak was detected significantly by lipase which has 25% increase of crystallinity, hence, by esterase, although the third peak was indicated at 18.5, the intensity of peak are smaller than by esterase treatment because of there is few change of crystallinity. Therefore, through experimental XRD, we concluded that structural changes were caused by enzyme treatment that produced the highest hydrolytic activity of the PLA fibers.

We confirmed through experimentation that the appearances of the PLA fabrics were changed and the hydrophilic properties were improved after enzymatic hydrolysis. Also, the hydrolytic activity of the enzyme resulted in structural changes to the fiber.

sec.title: Hydrophilic properties
sec.p:
The hydrophilic properties were evaluated on the basis of moisture regain and surface wettability, including the water contact angle (WCA). Figure 7 shows the moisture regain of PLA fabrics treated with enzymes under optimum hydrolytic activity conditions. As shown in Figure 7, the moisture regain was improved by enzymatic treatment. The moisture regain of untreated PLA fabric was 0.72% ± 0.03%; enzymatic treatment resulted in an approximately twofold improvement in moisture regain. The moisture regain of PLA fabrics was 1.49% ± 0.03% by lipase and 1.53% ± 0.16% by esterase. In spite of increasing crystallinity by enzymatic hydrolysis, moisture regain of enzyme-treated PLA fabrics was increased. This can be explained by some factors. First, the increase in moisture regain with enzymatic treatment indicated that enzymatic hydrolysis is concentrated on ester linkages and facilitated by the hydroxyl and carboxyl groups produced in PLA fabrics.19 Increasing of carboxyl concentration due to polymer hydrolysis made PLA fabrics hydrophilic.26 Second, microbubbles from weak biodeterioration by enzymatic hydrolysis resulting in increase of moisture regain.28,29 Even though amorphous region of PLA fiber were decreased, the surface of the fiber could be hydrophilic because of microorganisms formed on the fiber surface by biodeterioration. Third, crystallinity was influenced by the fiber; however, the moisture regain was measured by the fabric form. Therefore, moisture regain did not only relate to crystallinity unconditionally, but also the pore size of the fabric or space between the weave. Figure 8 indicates the surface wettability through the WCA of PLA fabrics treated by enzymes under optimum hydrolytic activity conditions. As shown in Figure 8, the WCA of untreated PLA fabric was 85° ± 4°. The WCA decreased to 79° ± 2° after lipase treatment and 84° ± 6° after esterase treatment. In general, the WCA decreased with hydrolysis of the fiber surface.33 In this study, even though the moisture regain increased drastically, the WCA showed a decrease. It is due to the difference in moisture particle sizes which are used to measure the moisture regain and the WCA. The moisture regain examined conditioning in 65% of relative humidity for 24 hours, so fine particles of moisture could permeate into the hydrolyzed PLA fabrics; however, the WCA was measured with larger particles, 3 μl of water drops. Thus, it causes the significant difference between the moisture regain and the WCA results. From the results based on the moisture regain and WCA, the hydrophilic properties of PLA fabrics are improved after enzymatic treatment. Figure 7.
Moisture regain of enzyme-treated PLA fabrics at optimum hydrolytic activity conditions (treatment conditions: pH 8.0, temperature of 40°C, enzyme concentration of 10% owf in the presence of 10 mM of CaCl2 for 60 min). Figure 8.
WCA of enzyme-treated PLA fabrics at optimum hydrolytic activity conditions (treatment conditions: pH 8.0, temperature of 40°C, enzyme concentration of 10% owf in the presence of 10 mM of CaCl2 for 60 min).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: To establish a bio-refinery of PLA fibers, we evaluated the hydrolytic activities of lipase and esterase for PLA fibers. We also established the optimal hydrolytic treatment conditions for the enzymes, which are pH 8.0, a temperature of 40°C, and an enzyme concentration of 10% owf for 60 min. Calcium chloride is an effective activator of lipase and esterase and the optimal concentration is 10 mM.

PLA fabrics experienced weight losses of about 0.62% and 0.75% from lipase and esterase treatment, respectively, but there was no significant decrease in tensile strength. In SEM images, we confirmed that hydrolysis on the fiber surface begins with microbubbles.

There was an approximately 2.0-fold improvement in moisture regain as a result of the enzyme treatment, and the WCA was decreased. The XRD pattern results revealed a new peak localized at 2θ = 18.5° after enzymatic treatment. The degree of crystallinity was increased and the crystallite size was decreased.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the Sookmyung Women’s University (Research Grants 2011 1-1103-0622).
